currentDoc:
Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion,

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. I believe that colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes. Colleges would have to cut funding for other activities.

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. I believe that colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes. Colleges would have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots.

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. I believe that colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes. Colleges would have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super 
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.

 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. I believe that colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes. Colleges would have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs whe
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. I believe that colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes. Colleges would have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everythi
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.

A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash. 
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have worse

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash. 
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.

A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash. 
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for that poorer students had

A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash. 
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for success of some student

McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash.  In a society alread
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for success of some students.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash.  In a society already dominated by money
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for success of some students.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash.  In a society already dominated by money, we'd jsut be al
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for success of some students.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash.  In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for success of some students.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash.  The money would go to a select few athletes, leaving the rest of the team with less. In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motisuccess of some students.

The money would go to a select few athletes, leaving the rest of the team with less. In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash.  The money would go to a select few athletes, leaving the rest of the team with less. In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motivation and success of some students.  There would be inequality

 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash-boug.  The money would go to a select few athletes, leaving the rest of the team with less. In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motivation and success of some students.  There would be inequality in payment, and inequality in opportunity.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash-bought top talent.  The money would go to a select few athletes, leaving the rest of the team with less. In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motivation and success of some students.  There would be inequality in payment, and inequality in opportunity.  
The NCAA is a non-profit organization.
 It is a community of schools, and the athletes are part of that community. I

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash-bought top talent.  The money would go to a select few athletes, leaving the rest of the team with less. In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motivation and success of some students.  There would be inequality in payment, and inequality in opportunity.  
The NCAA is a non-profit organization.
 It is a community of schools, and the athletes are part of that community. It works to keep schoo

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash-bought top talent.  The money would go to a select few athletes, leaving the rest of the team with less. In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motivation and success of some students.  There would be inequality in payment, and inequality in opportunity.  
The NCAA is a non-profit organization.
 It is a community of schools, and the athletes are part of that community. It works to keep schools a place of learni

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash-bought top talent.  The money would go to a select few athletes, leaving the rest of the team with less. In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motivation and success of some students.  There would be inequality in payment, and inequality in opportunity.  
The NCAA is a non-profit organization.
 It is a community of schools, and the athletes are part of that community. It works to keep schools a place of learning, returning all of

A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash-bought top talent.  The money would go to a select few athletes, leaving the rest of the team with less. In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motivation and success of some students.  There would be inequality in payment, and inequality in opportunity.  
The NCAA is a non-profit organization.
 It is a community of schools, and the athletes are part of that community. It returning all of its profits to the schools.It works to keep schools a place of learning,

A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash-bought top talent.  The money would go to a select few athletes, leaving the rest of the team with less. In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motivation and success of some students.  There would be inequality in payment, and inequality in opportunity.  
The NCAA is a non-profit organization.
 It is a community of schools, and the athletes are part of that community. It returns all of its profits to the schools and the fur.It works to keep schools a place of learning,

But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash-bought top talent.  The money would go to a select few athletes, leaving the rest of the team with less. In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motivation and success of some students.  There would be inequality in payment, and inequality in opportunity.  
The NCAA is a non-profit organization.
 It is a community of schools, and the athletes are part of that community. It returns all of its profits to the schools and the furth.It works to keep schools a place of learning,

McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash-bought top talent.  The money would go to a select few athletes, leaving the rest of the team with less. In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motivation and success of some students.  There would be inequality in payment, and inequality in opportunity.  
The NCAA is a non-profit organization.
 It is a community of schools, and the athletes are part of that community. It returns all of its profits to the schools and the furthering of altheti.It works to keep schools a place of learning,

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash-bought top talent.  The money would go to a select few athletes, leaving the rest of the team with less. In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motivation and success of some students.  There would be inequality in payment, and inequality in opportunity.  
The NCAA is a non-profit organization.
 It is a community of schools, and the athletes are part of that community. It returns all of its profits to the schools and the furthering of athleti.It works to keep schools a place of learning,

 It is a community of schools, and the athletes are part of that community. It returns all of its profits to the schools and the furthering of athletic programs. It works to keep schools a place of learning, not a place of money and greed. 
I believe that the NCAA is a great organization, and I believe that it should stay that way.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash-bought top talent.  The money would go to a select few athletes, leaving the rest of the team with less. In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motivation and success of some students.  There would be inequality in payment, and inequality in opportunity.  
The NCAA is a non-profit organization.

I believe that the NCAA is a great organization, and I believe that it should stay that way.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash-bought top talent.  The money would go to a select few athletes, leaving the rest of the team with less. In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motivation and success of some students.  There would be inequality in payment, and inequality in opportunity.  
The NCAA is a non-profit organization.
 It is a community of schools, and the athletes are part of that community. It returns all of its profits to the schools and the furthering of athletic programs. It works to keep schools a place of learning, not a place of money and greed. 
I believe that the NCAA is a great organization, and I believe that it should stay that way.
 College athletes can wait a few years

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash-bought top talent.  The money would go to a select few athletes, leaving the rest of the team with less. In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motivation and success of some students.  There would be inequality in payment, and inequality in opportunity.  
The NCAA is a non-profit organization.
 It is a community of schools, and the athletes are part of that community. It returns all of its profits to the schools and the furthering of athletic programs. It works to keep schools a place of learning, not a place of money and greed. 
I believe that the NCAA is a great organization, and I believe that it should stay that way.

McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash-bought top talent.  The money would go to a select few athletes, leaving the rest of the team with less. In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motivation and success of some students.  There would be inequality in payment, and inequality in opportunity.  
The NCAA is a non-profit organization.
 It is a community of schools, and the athletes are part of that community. It returns all of its profits to the schools and the furthering of athletic programs. It works to keep schools a place of learning, not a place of money and greed. 
I believe that the NCAA is a great organization, and I believe that it should stay that way.

In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motivation and success of some students.  There would be inequality in payment, and inequality in opportunity.  
The NCAA is a non-profit organization.
 It is a community of schools, and the athletes are part of that community. It returns all of its profits to the schools and the furthering of athletic programs. It works to keep schools a place of learning, not a place of money and greed.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash-bought top talent.  The money would go to a select few athletes, leaving the rest of the team with less. In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motivation and success of some students.  There would be inequality in payment, and inequality in opportunity.  
The NCAA is a non-profit organization.
 It is a community of schools, and the athletes are part of that community. It returns all of its profits to the schools and the furthering of athletic programs. It works to keep schools a place of learning, not a place of money and greed. 
I believe that the NCAA is a great organization, and I believe that it should stay that way.
 College athletes can wait a few years to go pro, and we should keep money from destroying a good system.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash-bought top talent.  The money would go to a select few athletes, leaving the rest of the team with less. In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motivation and success of some students.  There would be inequality in payment, and inequality in opportunity.  
The NCAA is a non-profit organization.
 It is a community of schools, and the athletes are part of that community. It returns all of its profits to the schools and the furthering of athletic programs. It works to keep schools a place of learning, not a place of money and bu. 
I believe that the NCAA is a great organization, and I believe that it should stay that way.
 We should keep money and greed from destroying a good system.

McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans, train and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash-bought top talent.  The money would go to a select few athletes, leaving the rest of the team with less. In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motivation and success of some students.  There would be inequality in payment, and inequality in opportunity.  
The NCAA is a non-profit organization.
 It is a community of schools, and the athletes are part of that community. It returns all of its profits to the schools and the furthering of athletic programs. It works to keep schools a place of learning, not a place of money and business. 
I believe that the NCAA is a great organization, and I believe that it should stay that way.
 We should keep money and greed from destroying a good system.

In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motivation and success of some students.  There would be inequality in payment, and inequality in opportunity.  
The NCAA is a non-profit organization.
 It is a community of schools, and the athletes are part of that community. It returns all of its profits to the schools and the furthering of athletic programs. It works to keep schools a place of learning, not a place of money and business. 
I believe that the NCAA is a great organization, and I believe that it should stay that way.
 We should keep money and greed from destroying a good system.

McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. I believe that the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans, training with a professional progr and the chance to get a college education is enough. 
I believe that paying college athletes would ruin college sports.
 I believe that paying college athletes would cause a bidding war between colleges. Colleges would have to overpay for a handful of athletes, and have to cut funding for other activities.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash-bought top talent.  The money would go to a select few athletes, leaving the rest of the team with less. In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motivation and success of some students.  There would be inequality in payment, and inequality in opportunity.  
The NCAA is a non-profit organization.
 It is a community of schools, and the athletes are part of that community. It returns all of its profits to the schools and the furthering of athletic programs. It works to keep schools a place of learning, not a place of money and business. 
I believe that the NCAA is a great organization, and I believe that it should stay that way.
 We should keep money and greed from destroying a good system.

There would be no "underdog with a chance to win", no dark horses, just the haves, and the have-nots. We'd have a few super-programs who dominated everything due to their excessive cash-bought top talent.  The money would go to a select few athletes, leaving the rest of the team with less. In a society already dominated by money, we'd just be allowing another thing to become "pay-to-win".
IPying college athletes would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni.
 Rural and poorer schools would have losing teams, harming the opportunities for motivation and success of some students.  There would be inequality in payment, and inequality in opportunity.  
The NCAA is a non-profit organization.
 It is a community of schools, and the athletes are part of that community. It returns all of its profits to the schools and the furthering of athletic programs. It works to keep schools a place of learning, not a place of money and business. 
I believe that the NCAA is a great organization, and I believe that it should stay that way.
 We should keep money and greed from destroying a good system.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---
